commit.message:
Pass Slack API token in Secret

Closes #13

It used to be that using `kubectl get pod -i yaml xyz` on the kubewise
pod would show the Slack API token in cleartext. With this change it is
stored in a secret instead. The external user interface doesn't change.

commit.message:
sops-nix example

I'm not yet sure whether I'd be better served by sops-nix or agenix.
This is just a proof-of-concept. I followed the instructions found at:
https://github.com/Mic92/sops-nix#usage-example

I generated an age key for my user:

    mkdir -p ~/.config/sops/age
    age-keygen -o ~/.config/sops/age/keys.txt

as well as an age key for thinkpad9:

    nix-shell -p ssh-to-age --run 'ssh-to-age -i /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key.pub'

Then, as the root user, I set up the secrets configuration to permit
decryption with these keys:

    sudo -i
    cd /etc/nixos/
    mkdir -p sops-nix/secrets
    nix-shell -p sops --run "SOPS_AGE_KEY_FILE=/home/${SUDO_USER:-$USER}/.config/sops/age/keys.txt sops sops-nix/secrets/secrets.yaml"

After a `nixos-rebuild switch`, the example secret is stored in
cleartext with restricted permissions:

    # cat /run/secrets/example_key
    example_value

    # ls -l /run/secrets/example_key
    -r-------- 1 root root 13 Aug 11 23:10 /run/secrets/example_key

Added entombment of secrets

[*Major Security Improvement*]

* This release introduces 'entombment' of Vault secrets into Credhub for
  increased security in the transport of your secrets on deployment.

  In previous versions, the `(( vault ... ))` operators in the manifest
  fragments, your environment and ops/ YAML files would resolve locally,
  placing the secrets needed from vault into the manifest.
  Unfortunately, this would be done in clear text.

  The alternative secret store is Credhub, and a few kits still use
  Credhub to contain the deployments secrets.  However, Credhub lacks
  the ability to manage your secrets as well as Vault, requiring a
  different tooling, or just simply deleting all secrets and allowing
  them to be generated again.  The final issue is that becase the
  placeholder variable doesn't change, there is no visual confirmation
  that you have changed the value of a Credhub secret on deployment.

  Genesis 2.9.0 brings you the best of both worlds!

  Vault remains the single source of truth, and you can manage your
  secrets with the Genesis add-secrets, check-secrets, rotate-secrets
  and remove-secrets commands, independent of the BOSH director.

  However, when it comes time to deploy your manifest, Genesis
  determines what Vault paths are being used by the manifest, pulls them
  into memory, runs a sha1sum on the values, then determines Credhub
  path to inject each of those Vault values into based on its vault path
  and value.  This results in a unique and idempotent variable that only
  changes if the value it contains changes.  The value is stored at that
  path in Credhub if it doesn't already exist.

  When merging the manifest, the vault operators now resolve to that
  unique Credhub path that contains the desired value, and there are no
  longer any cleartext secrets in the manifest, the log, or even if you
  pull down the manifest using the `bosh manifest` command.

  This is enabled on default for the `genesis deploy` command, and can
  be enabled using the `--entomb` option for the manifest and lookup
  commands.  Likewise, it can be disabled on the deploy command with
  --no-entomb option.  You can also set it as a local setting in your
  ~/.genesis/config file with `entomb_secrets` key that can be set true
  or false.  The command line options will take precedent over the
  config file.

  Note: The values are left in Credhub after the deploy to ensure any
  recreate or other BOSH operations that require the manifest to be
  intact still work.  Over time, this will result in Credhub containing
  values that are no longer used, including expired X509 certificates,
  which may trigger false positives in Doomsday cert expiry monitoring
  tool.  Future version of Genesis will enable cleaning out any old
  values that are no longer being used.

Support user-provided file realm and roles & refactor ES user management (#2682)


## Defining users and roles in Kubernetes secrets

This PR adds support for user-provided file realm and roles, through Kubernetes secrets.
File realm and roles secrets must be referenced in the Elasticsearch CRD. The secret content must match the file realm and file-based roles specification from the Elasticsearch documentation.

Example:

```yaml
apiVersion: elasticsearch.k8s.elastic.co/v1
kind: Elasticsearch
metadata:
  name: elasticsearch-sample
spec:
  version: 7.6.0
  auth:
    roles:
    - secretName: my-roles-1
    fileRealm:
    - secretName: my-filerealm-secret

---

# File realm in ES format (from the CLI or manually assembled)
kind: Secret
apiVersion: v1
metadata:
  name: my-filerealm-secret
stringData:
  users: |-
    rdeniro:$2a$10$BBJ/ILiyJ1eBTYoRKxkqbuDEdYECplvxnqQ47uiowE7yGqvCEgj9W
    alpacino:$2a$10$cNwHnElYiMYZ/T3K4PvzGeJ1KbpXZp2PfoQD.gfaVdImnHOwIuBKS
    jacknich:{PBKDF2}50000$z1CLJt0MEFjkIK5iEfgvfnA6xq7lF25uasspsTKSo5Q=$XxCVLbaKDimOdyWgLCLJiyoiWpA/XDMe/xtVgn1r5Sg=
  users_roles: |-
    admin:rdeniro
    power_user:alpacino,jacknich
    user:jacknich

---

# Roles in ES format
kind: Secret
apiVersion: v1
metadata:
  name: my-roles-1
stringData:
  roles.yml: |-
    click_admins:
      run_as: [ 'clicks_watcher_1' ]
      cluster: [ 'monitor' ]
      indices:
      - names: [ 'events-*' ]
        privileges: [ 'read' ]
        field_security:
          grant: ['category', '@timestamp', 'message' ]
        query: '{"match": {"category": "click"}}'
    another_role:
      cluster: [ 'all' ]
```

An aggregate secret is built from:
- predefined "internal" users (the `elastic` user, the readiness probe user, the controller user)
- associated users (from Kibana or APMServer associations)
- the user-provided file realm
- internal roles (the readiness probe custom role)
- user-provided roles
and mounted into all Elasticsearch Pods.

User-provided file realm and roles get precedence over internal ones.

This PR also adds an E2E test for user-provided file realm and roles.

## Refactoring

I decided to refactor our Elasticsearch user management code, because I had a hard time figuring out how the existing User and Credentials abstraction mapped to Kubernetes resources, and fitting the new file realm concept into it.

As a result of this refactoring:
- there is no more `Credentials` concept (hashed credentials vs. cleartext credentials)
- predefined users, associated users and user-provided users are separated in their own file
- there is no more common `User` pkg: it was actually mostly useful for Elasticsearch
- it is replaced by an internal private `user` type that can easily transform to a file realm
- association code may relies on the `elasticsearch/user/associated.go` code, which described an `AssociatedUser` and holds all the associated consts
- users reconciliations consists in building file realms for all sort of users and merging those together
- we don't inspect password vs. hash when updating secrets in the reconciler, through `credentials.NeedsUpdate()` (I think that part of the code was hard to grasp). Instead we just reuse existing passwords and hashes when building predefined users in the first place. The secret reconciliation is simpler imo.

Sorry for the super big PR including both the feature & refactoring. Doing one without the other did not make much sense.

------------------

Squashed commits:

* Add auth with filerealm and roles secret ref to the CRD

* Add a filerealm pkg to manipulate the filerealm content

* Manipulate roles in a dedicated file away from the file realm

* Remove the Credentials abstraction for simplification

* Simplify the user struct and generate a filerealm from it

* Reconcile predefined internal users

* Reconcile the user-provided file realm

* Add a helper function to watch user-provided secrets

* Remove the common user abstraction

* Replace the common ExternalUser by an es-specific AssociatedUser

* Move util functions from user to utils pkg

* Propagate constants move to import paths in other files

* Add string helper funcs

* Rename xpack file realm refs to roles + file realm

* Remove the previous users & file realm reconciliation

* Reconcile the aggregate file realm and roles

* The users reconciliation now returns a single controller user

* Add an E2E test for user-provided auth

* Fix linter warnings

* Emit an event but don't error out on referenced secret error

* Fix typos and comments

* The internal roleUsersMapping should always be sorted

* Add unit tests for users and users_roles parsing

* Consistent error format

* Regenerate CRDs

* Rename esclient.UserAuth to esclient.BasicAuth

* Rename files to be closer to file realm concepts

* Rename roleUsersMapping to usersRoles to avoid confusion

* Fix comments

* Remove roles and file realm secret watches on ES deletion

* Fixes from PR review

* Regenerate CRDs and api docs

* Regenerate CRDs and api docs
